user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of new_connections_list_process_:
```c
static void
new_connections_list_process_ (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *local_head;
  struct MHD_Connection *local_tail;
  mhd_assert (daemon->have_new);
  mhd_assert (MHD_D_IS_THREAD_SAFE_ (daemon));

  /* Detach DL-list of new connections from the daemon for
   * following local processing. */
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);
  mhd_assert (NULL != daemon->new_connections_head);
  local_head = daemon->new_connections_head;
  local_tail = daemon->new_connections_tail;
  daemon->new_connections_head = NULL;
  daemon->new_connections_tail = NULL;
  daemon->have_new = false;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->new_connections_mutex);
  (void) local_head; /* Mute compiler warning */

  /* Process new connections in FIFO order. */
  do
  {
    struct MHD_Connection *c;   /**< Currently processed connection */

    c = local_tail;
    DLL_remove (local_head,
                local_tail,
                c);
    mhd_assert (daemon == c->daemon);
    if (MHD_NO == new_connection_process_ (daemon, c))
    {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (daemon,
                _ ("Failed to start serving new connection.\n"));
#endif
      (void) 0;
    }
  } while (NULL != local_tail);

}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the entire provided function. It contains only pointer assignments, assertions, mutex lock/unlock, linked-list manipulation (DLL_remove), a call to new_connection_process_, and conditional logging macros. There are no calls to any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.), nor are there any direct string/byte-buffer manipulations or pointer arithmetic on character buffers in this snippet that could cause out-of-bounds accesses related to those functions. The only external identifiers that might perform such operations are DLL_remove and new_connection_process_, but their implementations are not present in this fragment; they would need to be reviewed separately if available. Therefore there are no code fragments in this snippet that require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
